{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3479723,"name":"Johnathon","username":"Upcoming","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/u/a5b964/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-12T03:47:25.171Z","cooked":"

Hello! me and my team are trying out sysID this year in hopes of achieving more accurate feed forward values when tuning our arm. Prior to this we just applied a voltage until it overcame gravity to find kg and put it upright until it moved to find the ks. Is there a test you can run for the arm similar to how phoenix6 2025 added the SysIdRoutine class for the swerve drivetrain. Any help is appreciated!

WPILib has a class for running SysId routines.

I was playing around with that class and tried creating a routine for our arm subsystem but I wasn’t sure if I was doing it right. This is the code I wrote for it

image1074×897 77.7 KB

I basically just copied the routine for drive and replaced the motor it used with our arm_motor. I wasn’t sure if this was the right way to run a routine for the arm and even though it logged the arm_state string, it did not log the actual arm_motor.

As you can see in the image the Arm_State string is present as it should be but the phoenix6 folder only contains the drive motors and steer motors.

TLDR: What would be the proper process for running a sysID routine for an arm and how do I log the motor outputs into the log file.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-01-12T17:27:31.939Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":148,"readers_count":147,"score":49.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":481116,"topic_slug":"using-sysid-to-tune-arm","display_username":"Johnathon","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":12381,"username":"Oblarg","name":"Eli Barnett","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49222,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"tired"},"post_url":"/t/using-sysid-to-tune-arm/481116/3","custom_user_title":"tired","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3480238,"name":"Johnathon","username":"Upcoming","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/u/a5b964/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-12T19:56:36.711Z","cooked":"

Update:
I looked through WPI Libs documentation for SysID and found examples on using SysID for the arm. The example they show uses the WPILIB Encoder class and uses the getDistance() function in order to return values for position and getRate() to return values for velocity. getDistance returns the change in distance between loops and getRate returns the “current rate of the encoder” which I assume means the distance the encoder changes every second. However this encoder class requires a port A and port B. My team is using cancoders so I do not think they fit into the Encoder class. I’ve looked through the documentation for Cancoders and have not found functions that return values similar to the ones getDistance and getRate return. This is what my code looks like now but I am not sure if the functions I am using are what I need for sysID.

image1800×648 81.8 KB

The class does not itself care where the data values come from; there is no tight coupling to the Encoder API.

Thank you for your help so far! I found out how to log the test and get it into sysID but the values I am getting are nonsensical.

image1888×1032 295 KB

In the test above I input the motor velocity, position, and voltage and the resulting graphs are very weird. And the ff values are probably wrong as well. I also tried to feed in the Cancoder values for position and velocity and they are not much better shown below.

image1908×1038 295 KB

I am running the quasistatic and dynamic tests by just moving the arm up and down as it would in a match. During the test the arm falls without motor input so could this cause error in some way. Any info on the actual process of running the tests would be very helpful. Thank you!

You won’t be able to succeed in performing system identification if you can’t troubleshoot your data streams and ensure they’re returning the values you think they are, in the units you think they should. Until you do that, trying to run a routine is putting the cart before the horse.
